query: MMP for Calabi-Yau fibrations
paper: Moduli of surfaces fibered in log Calabi-Yau pairs
body-only-v1: Minimal model program for log Calabi-Yau fibrations: Given a klt generalized pair morphism with relative log Calabi-Yau condition and ample boundary divisor, any MMP on the base lifts to birational contractions on the total space. The proper transform of the boundary remains ample over each step, and relative dimension one is preserved. For morphism steps, weak canonical models are obtained, and KSBA-stable limits become independent of small perturbations.
body-and-summary-v1: The minimal model program for log Calabi-Yau fibrations establishes that running MMP on the base generalized pair induces compatible birational contractions on the total space, preserving ampleness and relative dimension properties, with applications to KSBA-stable limits in moduli theory.
body-and-introduction-v1: Let R be a DVR and pi: (X,D) -> (Y,B_Y+M) -> Spec R be a morphism of klt generalized pairs such that pi*(K_Y+B_Y+M) is Q-linearly equivalent to K_X+D and D is pi-ample. Given an MMP with scaling for (Y,B_Y+M), one can lift it to a sequence of birational contractions for (X,D). The proper transform D(i) remains ample over Y(i), and if pi has relative dimension one, then pi(k) also has relative dimension one and preserves the log Calabi-Yau condition. If the p(i) are morphisms, then (X(k),(1+epsilon)D(k)) is a weak canonical model for (X,(1+epsilon)D) over Y(k) for small epsilon. In particular, if K_Y(k)+B_Y(k)+M(k) is ample and (X,D) -> Spec R is locally stable with stable generic fiber, then the KSBA-stable limit of (X_eta,(1+epsilon)D_eta) is independent of small epsilon.
body: [MMP for log Calabi-Yau fibrations] Let $R$ be a DVR, and $\pi\colon \left(X,D\right)\to (Y,B_Y+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\})\rightarrow \\text\{Spec\} R$ be a morphism of klt generalized pairs. Assume that $$\textstyle \pi^*(K_Y+B_Y+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\}) \ \sim_{\mathbb Q} \ K_X +D$$ and that $D$ is $\pi$-ample. Then given an MMP with scaling for the generalized pair $(Y,B_Y+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\})$ one can make it follow by a sequence of birational contractions for $(X,D)$: $$\begin{tikzcd} {\big(X,D\big)} & {\big(X^{(1)},D^{(1)}\big)} & \cdots & {\big(X^{(k)},D^{(k)}\big)} \\ {\big(Y,B_Y+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\})} & {\big(Y^{(1)},B_Y^{(1)}+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\}^{(1)}\big)} & \cdots & {\big(Y^{(k)},B_Y^{(k)}+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\}^{(k)}\big)} \arrow["{q^{(0)}}", dotted, from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow["{\pi}", from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow["{q^{(1)}}", dotted, from=1-2, to=1-3] \arrow["{\pi^{(1)}}", dotted, from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow["{q^{(k-1)}}", dotted, from=1-3, to=1-4] \arrow[dotted, from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow["{\pi^{(k)}}", dotted, from=1-4, to=2-4] \arrow["{p^{(0)}}", dotted,from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow["{p^{(1)}}", dotted,from=2-2, to=2-3] \arrow["{p^{(k-1)}}", dotted,from=2-3, to=2-4] \end{tikzcd}.$$ Moreover, the following holds: \begin{enumerate} \item the proper transform $D^{(i)}$ of $D$ remains ample over $Y^{(i)}$; \item if $\pi$ has relative dimension one, then $\pi^{(k)}$ has relative dimension one and \[(\pi^{(k)})^*(K_{Y^{(k)}}+B_Y^{(k)}+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\}^{(k)})\sim_{\mathbb Q} K_{X^{(k)}} +D^{(k)};\] \item if $p^{(i)}$ are morphisms, then $\big(X^{(k)},(1+\epsilon)D^{(k)}\big)$ is a weak canonical model for $\big(X,(1+\epsilon)D\big)$ over $Y^{(k)}$, for $0<\epsilon \ll 1$. \end{enumerate} In particular, if $K_{Y^{(k)}} + B_Y^{(k)}+\\text\{\{\bf\{M\}\}\}^{(i)}$ is ample and $(X,D)\to \text{\rm Spec} R$ is locally stable with stable generic fiber, then the KSBA-stable limit of $\big(X_\eta,(1 +\epsilon)D_\eta\big)$ is independent of $0<\epsilon\ll 1$.

body: Let $G \to \operatorname{Spec} R$ be a reductive group which is either special or has tame Weyl group. Then any class $\mathcal{G} \in \operatorname{H}^2(R,G)$ which is trivial over $\\text\{Spec\} K$ becomes trivial after passing to a root stack. In particular, if $\mathcal{G}|_K = 0$ then $\mathcal{G}|_k = 0$.

body-and-introduction-v1: A smooth tame Deligne-Mumford stack is uniquely determined by its coarse moduli space and codimension one ramification data. body: Let $X$ be a separated $k$-scheme of finite type and suppose $U$ is a dense open subscheme of $X$ with complement of codimension $\geq 2$. Consider the coarse moduli map $\mathcal{U} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{cms}} U$ where $\mathcal{U}$ is a smooth tame Deligne-Mumford stack and let $(D,\mathbf{e})$ denote the (unique) extension of the ramification data of $\mathcal{U} \to U^{\mathrm{can}}$ to $X^{\mathrm{can}}$, when the latter exists. If $X$ and $\sqrt{X^{\mathrm{can}}/(D,\mathbf{e})}$ both have finite tame quotient singularities, then there is a unique smooth tame Deligne-Mumford stack $\mathcal{X}$ fitting into the cartesian square $$ \begin{tikzcd} \mathcal{U} \arrow[d] \arrow[r, dashed, hook, "\mathrm{open}"] & \mathcal{X} \arrow[d, dashed, "\mathrm{cms}"] \\ U \arrow[r, hook] & X. \end{tikzcd} $$

Note that there is an identification of GIT quotients $(W \times^{G_x} G) /\!\!/ G \cong W /\!\!/ G_x$.} If $X$ admits a good GIT quotient $X \to X /\!\!/ G$, then it is possible to arrange that the induced morphism $W /\!\!/ G_x \to X /\!\!/ G$ is \'etale and $W \times^{G_x} G \cong W /\!\!/ G_x \times_{X /\!\!/ G} X$. Let $N_x = T_{X,x} / T_{G \cdot x, x}$ be the normal space to the orbit at $x$; this inherits a natural linear action of $G_x$. If $x \in X$ is smooth, then it can be arranged that there is an \'etale $G_x$-equivariant morphism $W \to N_x$ such that $W /\!\!/ G_x \to N_x /\!\!/ G_x$ is \'etale and $$\xymatrix{ N_x \times^{G_x} G \ar[d] & W \times^{G_x} G\ar[r]^-{\tilde f} \ar[d] \ar[l] & X \\ N_x /\!\!/ G_x & W /\!\!/ G_x \ar[l] \ar@{}[ul]|\square & }$$ is cartesian.

body: Let $\pi\colon\mathcal{X}\to Y$ be a good moduli space with $Y$ proper (equivalently, by \cite[Theorem A]{AHLH}, $\mathcal{X}$ is $\Theta$-reductive, $\textbf{S}$-complete, and satisfies the existence part of the valuative criterion). Let $\mathcal{E}$ be a finite rank vector bundle and $\alpha\colon\mathcal{E}\twoheadrightarrow\mathcal{Q}$ a surjection to a locally free sheaf. Assume \begin{enumerate} \item there exists $N>0$ such that $\det(\mathcal{Q})^{\otimes N}$ descends to a line bundle $\mathcal{L}$ on $Y$, \item the fibers of $[\alpha]$ contain finitely many closed points, and \item one of the following holds: \begin{enumerate} \item $\mathcal{E}$ is weakly semi-positive with linearly reductive structure group $G$, or \item\label{kollar::Schur-positive} $\mathcal{E}=\rho(\mathcal{E}_1,\dots,\mathcal{E}_k)$ where the $\mathcal{E}_i$ are weakly semi-positive vector bundles of rank $n_i$, $G=\prod_i\\text\{GL\}_{n_i}$ and $\rho$ is a semi-positive polynomial representation, or \item for every map $f\colon C\to\mathcal{X}$ from a curve whose generic point maps to the polystable locus $\mathcal{X}^{\\text\{ps\}}$, $f^*\mathcal{E}\simeq\mathcal{E}'\otimes\mathcal{M}$, where $\mathcal{M}$ has degree $0$ and $\mathcal{E}'$ is of the form (\ref{kollar::Schur-positive}). \end{enumerate} \end{enumerate} Then $\mathcal{L}$ is ample, hence $Y$ is projective.

body: Let $K=k(C)$ be the function field of a smooth projective curve $C$, let $f\colon C\dasharrow\mathcal{P}(\vec{\lambda})$ be a rational map, and let $P\in\mathcal{P}_{C}(\vec\lambda)(K)$ denote the corresponding rational point, where $\mathcal{P}_{C}(\vec\lambda)=\mathcal{P}(\vec{\lambda})\times C\to C$ is the constant family. Let $\{x_j\}$ be the indeterminacy points of $f$. Assume the $\lambda_i$ are prime to the characteristic of the ground field. \begin{enumerate} \item\label{thm:tuning-stacks-and-minimal-linear-series::tuning-stack} Let $(L,s_0,\dots,s_N)$ be any ${\vec{\lambda}}$-weighted linear series inducing $f$. Then the universal tuning stack $(\mathcal{C},\pi,\overline{P})$ of $P$ is the root stack of $C$ obtained by taking the $r_j$-th root at $x_j$, where $r_j=r_{\min}(x_j;L,s_0,\dots,s_N)$. Moreover, the induced morphism on stabilizers over $x_j$ is given by the character $\chi_j^{-a_j}$ where $a_j = a_{\min}(x_j, L, s_0, \ldots, s_N)$. \item\label{thm:tuning-stacks-and-minimal-linear-series::minimal-lin-ser} There exists a unique minimal ${\vec{\lambda}}$-weighted linear series inducing $f$. \item\label{thm:tuning-stacks-and-minimal-linear-series::height} The stacky height $\\text\{ht\}_{\mathcal{O}(1)}(P)$ is equal to $\deg L$ where $(L, s_0, \dots, s_N)$ is the unique minimal linear series. Moreover, the stable height is given by $\\text\{ht\}_{\mathcal{O}(1)}^{st}(P) = \deg \overline{P}^*\mathcal{O}(1)$ and the local contribution at $x_j$ is given by $\delta_{x_j}(P) = \frac{a_j}{r_j}[k(x_j):k]$. \end{enumerate}

body: Let $X$ be a projective normal variety and let $D$ be a $\mathbb{R}$-Cartier $\mathbb{R}$-divisor on $X$. Let $S$ be a base point free Cartier prime divisor on $X$. The stabilizer group acts trivially on a point in the affine scheme that maps to the original closed point.
body: Let $X$ be an Artin stack with a good moduli space $q\colon X \to Y$ such that $X_\mathrm{cl}$ satisfies the conditions listed above. Let $x \in |X|$ be a closed point and write $G_x$ for the classical stabilizer group of $x \in |X_\mathrm{cl}|$. The parameter space decomposes into chambers where moduli spaces are isomorphic. For weights in different chambers with decreasing coefficients, canonical birational maps connect moduli spaces. body-and-introduction-v1: For a family of smooth normal crossings pairs over a smooth connected base and a finite rational polytope of weight vectors such that each yields a family of stable pairs, there is a finite rational polyhedral wall-and-chamber decomposition. For weights in the same chamber, the normalized closures of the image of the base in the moduli spaces are canonically isomorphic, as are their universal families. For weights in different chambers with coefficients non-increasing, there are canonical birational wall-crossing morphisms between these normalized moduli spaces that compose compatibly. These morphisms are induced by birational maps between universal families such that on a generic fiber, the map gives the canonical model for the pair with the smaller weight coefficients.
body: Let $(X,D_1, \ldots, D_n) \to B$ be a family of smooth normal crossings pairs over a smooth connected base $B$ and let $P$ be a finite, rational polytope of weight vectors $\mathbf{a} = (a_1, \ldots, a_n)$ such that $a_i < 1$ and $(X, \sum a_iD_i) \to B$ is a family of stable pairs for each $\mathbf{a} \in P$. Let $\mathscr{N}_\mathbf{a}$ denote the normalized closure of the image of $B$ in the moduli space of $\mathbf{a}$-weighted stable pairs with universal family of stable pairs $(\mathcal X_\mathbf{a}, \sum a_i \mathcal D_i) \to \mathscr{N}_{\mathbf{a}}$. Then there exists a finite, rational polyhedral wall-and-chamber decomposition of $P$ such that the following hold. \begin{enumerate}[(a)] \item For $\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{a}'$ contained in the same chamber, there are canonical isomorphisms $$ \xymatrix{\mathcal X_\mathbf{a} \ar[r]^{\cong} \ar[d] & \mathcal X_{\mathbf{a}'} \ar[d] \\ \mathscr{N}_\mathbf{a} \ar[r]^{\cong} & \mathscr{N}_{\mathbf{a}'}. } $$ \item For $\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b} \in P$ contained in different chambers and satisfying $b_i \le a_i$ for all $i$, there are canonical birational wall-crossing morphisms $$ \rho_{\mathbf{b}, \mathbf{a}} : \mathscr{N}_{\mathbf{a}} \to \mathscr{N}_{\mathbf{b}} $$ such that for any third weight vector $\mathbf{c}$ with $c_i \le b_i$, we have $\rho_{\mathbf{c}, \mathbf{b}} \circ \rho_{\mathbf{b}, \mathbf{a}} = \rho_{\mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}}$. Moreover, the map $\rho_{\mathbf{b}, \mathbf{a}}$ is induced by a birational map $h^{b,a} : \mathcal X_\mathbf{a} \dashrightarrow \rho_{\mathbf{b}, \mathbf{a}}^*\mathcal X_{\mathbf{b}}$ such that, for a generic $u \in \mathscr{N}_\mathbf{a}$, the fiberwise map $h^{b,a}_u : (\mathcal X_\mathbf{a})_u \dashrightarrow (\mathcal X_{\mathbf{b}})_{\rho_{\mathbf{b}, \mathbf{a}}(u)}$ is the canonical model of $((\mathcal X_\mathbf{a})_u, \sum b_i (\mathcal D_i)_u)$. \end{enumerate}

body-and-summary-v1: For any stable pair (Y,D_Y), there exists a Q-stable pair (X,D) that has (Y,D_Y) as its canonical model. This construction is part of a framework for building moduli spaces of Q-Gorenstein pairs with proper structure and projective coarse moduli. The approach prevents pathologies that occur in stable pair moduli spaces when coefficients are small. This machinery provides an alternative proof for the projectivity of stable pair moduli spaces.
body-and-introduction-v1: The canonical model of a stable pair (Y, D_Y) is a Q-stable pair (X, D) obtained by running the minimal model program on (Y, D_Y). This pair (X, D) has semi-log canonical singularities, and K_X + (1 - epsilon)D is ample for sufficiently small epsilon greater than 0.
